abstracts.cdata!:
The northern Aral Sea in Kazakhstan was
            choppy and water flushed through a sluice, washing down fish
            into a channel leading towards the southern Aral Sea. The
            new dike, financed by the World Bank, has helped raise water
            levels in a once-dying sea. That increase has revived local
            fisheries, restored hope in long-suffering communities, and
            even affected the microclimate - clouds in May and
            rainstorms used to be unheard of in an area parched by
            decades of environmental abuse. As more water became
            available for irrigation and fields were better protected
            from floods, more farmers were likely to place additional
            land in production. The next step was to improve the
            irrigation efficiency of two-thirds of the land in the
            Kazakh part of the Aral Sea basin. Additional waterworks
            were planned to restore wetlands and fishing lakes in the
            delta region.
